Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: I'd like to think that we've already *released* a beta version (a "beta release", cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle#Beta). And we're making new releases often! There are also concepts of a *stable release* (when we're happy with where we are), *opening the source* and *store release* (when the application is freely available in application store search and can be installed without subscribing to a beta testing).

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: I agree with James in that we need to improve the order matching before we can consider the AtomicDEX to be stable. And we have a number of other modifications on the way.

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: MM is an integral part of order matching, yes, but different layers can participate in it and in different capacity. Right now, for example, the user is essentially selecting a specific order. There is up-matching (an order with a better price can be used automatically), but if I select a best price (with no better prices past it) then I've essentially picked a specific order, which might be in fact unavailable due to a number of reasons.

Author: CryptoSurfer#5372

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess "not fully available" makes sense, but it is fully operational

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
initial version of the decentralized orderbook transport layer tested out better than expected with a limit of about 50,000 orders per hour and 4000 orders in one minute burst limit.
this is with the simplistic internal searching algo. still need to get it validated with much higher number of nodes than the 12 nodes i used, but this is a very good start and the goal of being able to handle much much higher levels of traffic is now within reach.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: one of the design goals was to minimize wasted bandwidth transmitting the same data to the same node, but still making it fast enough so orders propagate in a few seconds. in my three hour test of 30,000+ orders, all the nodes were 100% in sync and there was less than 1% of excess bandwidth

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: also this p2p layer in komodod is a general-purpose technology! (giving us more freedom in how to use it for order matching)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, for any usecase where 100% consensus isnt critical, this can be very handy. it is like UDP as opposed to TCP. usually it will be just fine, but if things get overloaded, it will start dropping packets randomly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: however, it shouldnt ever end up getting deadlocked and when the load reduces, things will get back in sync again

Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: interesting ux challenge I'm sure has been discussed. I have some KMD but can't trade my way into ETH unless I already have ETH on my wallet to pay for gas

Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: So, using the android app. if you create an order, do you need to have the app running when somebody fills it so that you can complete the trade? also, not sure if this is a bug but the app continuously makes the sound of coins clinking after I create an order

Author: ca333#0118
Content: yes - thats a limitation and affects ETH/ERC swaps only. Technically we likely could redesign the atomic-swap protocol in order to enforce the ETH/ERC side of a swap to cover all gas fees. This is something we might look into at some point.

Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: interesting

Author: ca333#0118
Content: `if you create an order, do you need to have the app running when somebody fills it so that you can complete the trade?` yes the app needs to run (at least in background mode) to execute swaps. There aren't only mobile clients/peers - the network also consists of a set of server/desktop based DEX nodes/peers.

Author: ca333#0118
Content: the background sound is a new and experimental feature and we are working on improving this - a new version is coming out very soon.

Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: haha OK thanks. there is a setting for whether to play at full volume but unfortunately it can't be muted entirely. So I'd have to walk around with my phone making that noise (it plays in the background as well) until somebody filled my order!
